definitions.definition: not existing before; recently made, invented, introduced, etc.

examples.text: Have you read her new novel?
We retrain staff to use the **new technology**.
The company is trialling a new security system.
Have you seen Danielle's new baby?
a new addition to the family *(= a baby)*
The school secretary wants to introduce new ways of doing things in the office.
This idea isn't new.
The latest model has over 100 new features.
Check out the band's new album.
There is nothing new in teenagers wanting to change the world.
These ideas are not entirely new.
The brand is still relatively new in the United States.
genuinely new approaches to data recording
It's a totally new and innovative design.
I'm knitting a teddy for the new baby due in July.
He drew a picture for his new baby brother.

definitions.definition: something that is new

examples.text: It was a good mix of the old and the new.

definitions.definition: recently bought

examples.text: Let me show you my new dress.
The car still looks new.
They are very proud of their spanking new kitchen.

definitions.definition: not used or owned by anyone before

examples.text: A second-hand car costs a fraction of a new one.
They are building 500 new houses in the town.

definitions.definition: different from the previous one

examples.text: I like your new hairstyle.
When do you start your new job?
He's made a lot of new friends.
Do you have her new phone number?
Jamila likes to try the new fashions coming in from Pakistan.
He couldn't stand the new breed of career politicians.

definitions.definition: already existing but not seen, experienced, etc. before; not familiar

examples.text: This is a new experience for me.
I'd like to learn a new language.
the discovery of a new star
Scientists have identified an **entirely new** species.
Manga is drawing in a **whole new** generation of readers.
to try/learn/do something new
Our system is probably new to you.
Hard work is nothing new to Bill.
It was all very new and strange to me.
The book has nothing new to say about the Stones.
Farming is a new way of life for many young people.

definitions.definition: not yet familiar with something because you have only just started, arrived, etc.

examples.text: You're new here, aren't you?
New arrivals should have their passports ready for inspection.
We offer intensive training to all new recruits.
I should tell you, I'm completely new to this kind of work.
I am new to the town.
New students will be given a tour of the college facilities.
I was fairly new to teaching at the time.
He was new to the job and had not known how to deal with the situation.
It's too much to ask of someone who is so new to the profession.
She's still quite new to the job and needs a lot of help.
You're new in this town, aren't you?

definitions.definition: just beginning or beginning again

examples.text: a new day
It was a new era in the history of our country.
She went to Australia to start a new life.

definitions.definition: used in compounds to describe something that has recently happened

examples.text: He was enjoying his new-found freedom.

definitions.definition: modern; of the latest type

examples.text: the new morality
They called themselves the New Romantics.

definitions.definition: having fresh energy, courage or health

examples.text: Since he changed jobs he's looked like a new man.

definitions.definition: only recently produced or developed

examples.text: The new buds are appearing on the trees now.
new potatoes *(= ones dug from the soil early in the season)*

definitions.definition: a situation or society that changes in a way that is meant to improve people’s lives but is often a source of extra problems

examples.text: the brave new world of technology
the architects' vision of a brave new world of pristine concrete

definitions.definition: to make a new discovery or do something that has not been done before

examples.text: Her architectural designs have broken new ground.

definitions.definition: to improve something by introducing new ideas and making people more interested in it

examples.text: The results of their research have breathed new life into the debate.
He hopes the development will breathe new life into the community.
They need some new, younger staff to breathe some life into the company.

definitions.definition: used to describe a situation in which everybody suddenly realizes that they were wrong to believe that somebody/something was very good, important, etc.

examples.text: Is this artist's white canvas a case of the emperor's new clothes or is it something beautiful, even moving?
Soon investors will realize that the emperor has no clothes and there will be a big sell-off in stocks.

definitions.definition: in very good condition, as it was when it was new

examples.text: I've had your coat cleaned—it's as good as new now.

definitions.definition: used to say that something has become very fashionable and can be thought of as replacing something else

examples.text: Brown is the new black.
Comedy is the new rock and roll.
Fifty is the new forty.

definitions.definition: new members or employees, especially young ones, with new ideas or ways of doing things

examples.text: This company badly needs to bring in some new blood.

definitions.definition: a person who has just started to work for an organization, department, etc., especially in a senior job, and who is likely to make a lot of changes

examples.text: Well, you know what they say—**a new broom sweeps clean**.

definitions.definition: a person who is new to a place, an organization, etc.

examples.text: Despite his six years in politics, he was still regarded by many as the new kid on the block.

definitions.definition: a situation that used to be unusual but is now what you should expect

examples.text: This is not a temporary blip—this is the new normal.
Scientists say these weather patterns could be the new normal for Florida.

definitions.definition: used to say that you have not heard a particular idea, piece of information, joke, etc. before

examples.text: ‘Have you come across this before?’ ‘No, it's a new one on me.’

definitions.definition: to change the way that a situation appears

examples.text: What you have told us puts a different complexion on the situation.
This puts a whole new complexion on the matter.

definitions.definition: to behave in a worse way than ever before

examples.text: The government has stooped to an all-time low with this policy.
Reality TV has sunk to new lows.

definitions.definition: (you cannot) successfully make people change their ideas, methods of work, etc., when they have had them for a long time
to change your way of life to become a better, more responsible person
used as a friendly greeting

examples.text: Hi! What's new?

wordOrigin: Old English nīwe, nēowe, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch nieuw and German neu, from an Indo-European root shared by Sanskrit nava, Latin novus, and Greek neos ‘new’.
